name: NCDHC Discharge Family Member History Profile
title: NCDHC Discharge Family Member History Profile
purpose: To record family history of the baby patient

element.short: Information about patient's relatives, relevant for patient
element.definition: Significant health events and conditions for a person related to the patient relevant in the context of care for the patient.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain any narrative
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource
Can only have estimatedAge if age[x] is present
Not Done Reason can only be specified if NotDone is "true"
Can have age[x] or born[x], but not both

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comment:
Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. 

This element is labelled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded in formation is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: This records identifiers associated with this family member history record that are defined by business processes and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
element.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CX / EI (occasionally, more often EI maps to a resource id or a URL)

II - see see identifier pattern at http://wiki.hl7.org/index.php?title=Common_Design_Patterns#Identifier_Pattern for relevant discussion. The Identifier class is a little looser than the v3 type II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs.  Also maps to Role[classCode=IDENT]

element.definition: A protocol or questionnaire that was adhered to in whole or in part by this event.
element.comment: References SHALL be a reference to an actual FHIR resource, and SHALL be resolveable (allowing for access control, temporary unavailability, etc). Resolution can be either by retrieval from the URL, or, where applicable by resource type, by treating an absolute reference as a canonical URL and looking it up in a local registry/repository.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.definition: A code specifying the status of the record of the family history of a specific family member.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A code that identifies the status of the family history record.

element.short: The taking of a family member's history did not occur
element.definition: If true, indicates the taking of an individual family member's history did not occur. The notDone element should not be used to document negated conditions, such as a family member that did not have a condition.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because it marks the family member history as a family member history that did not occur.  The more attributes are populated, the more constrained the negated statement is.  This notDone element is being evaluated and will likely be removed in a subsequent release.
element.requirements: Creating a FamilyMemberHistory where notDone is true is intended for situations where there's a need for a specific statement in the record about something not being done.  If the need is merely to indicate that a request wasn't fulfilled, that should be handled using Task.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Describes why the family member's history is absent.
element.comment: This notDoneReason element is being evaluated and will likely be replaced in a subsequent release (e.g. dataAbsentReason).
element.requirements: This is a separate element to allow it to have a distinct binding from reasonCode.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes describing the reason why a family member history was not done.

element.definition: The person who this history concerns.
element.comment: References SHALL be a reference to an actual FHIR resource, and SHALL be resolveable (allowing for access control, temporary unavailability, etc). Resolution can be either by retrieval from the URL, or, where applicable by resource type, by treating an absolute reference as a canonical URL and looking it up in a local registry/repository.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.definition: The date (and possibly time) when the family member history was taken.
element.comment: This should be captured even if the same as the date on the List aggregating the full family history.
element.requirements: Allows determination of how current the summary is.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: This will either be a name or a description; e.g. "Aunt Susan", "my cousin with the red hair".
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Allows greater ease in ensuring the same person is being talked about.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The type of relationship this person has to the patient (father, mother, brother etc.).
element.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the related person being described in the family member history.

element.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the relative is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Not all relationship codes imply gender and the relative's gender can be relevant for risk assessments.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes.

element.definition: The actual or approximate date of birth of the relative.
element.comment: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If duration is required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.
element.requirements: Allows calculation of the relative's age.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

mapping.map: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

element.definition: The age of the relative at the time the family member history is recorded.
element.comment: use estimatedAge to indicate whether the age is actual or not.
element.requirements: While age can be calculated from date of birth, sometimes recording age directly is more natureal for clinicians.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present
There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.  If value is present, it SHALL be positive.
constraint.expression: (code or value.empty()) and (system.empty() or system = %ucum) and (value.empty() or value > 0)
constraint.xpath: (f:code or not(f:value)) and (not(exists(f:system)) or f:system/@value='http://unitsofmeasure.org') and (not(f:value/@value) or f:value/@value >=0)

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

element.definition: If true, indicates that the age value specified is an estimated value.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the fact tha age is estimated can/should change the results of any algorithm that calculates based on the specified age.
element.requirements: Clinicians often prefer to specify an estimaged age rather than an age range.
element.meaningWhenMissing: It is unknown whether the age is an estimate or not

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Deceased flag or the actual or approximate age of the relative at the time of death for the family member history record.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: player[classCode=LIV, determinerCode=INSTANCE].deceasedInd, deceasedDate (could be URG)  For age, you'd hang an observation off the role

element.short: Why was family member history performed?
element.definition: Describes why the family member history occurred in coded or textual form.
element.comment: Textual reasons can be caprued using reasonCode.text.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes indicating why the family member history was done.

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: Why was family member history performed?
element.definition: Indicates a Condition, Observation, AllergyIntolerance, or QuestionnaireResponse that justifies this family member history event.

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.definition: This property allows a non condition-specific note to the made about the related person. Ideally, the note would be in the condition property, but this is not always possible.
element.comment: For systems that do not have structured annotations, they can simply communicate a single annotation with no author or time.  This element may need to be included in narrative because of the potential for modifying information.  *Annotations SHOULD NOT* be used to communicate "modifying" information that could be computable. (This is a SHOULD because enforcing user behavior is nearly impossible).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Condition that the related person had
element.definition: The significant Conditions (or condition) that the family member had. This is a repeating section to allow a system to represent more than one condition per resource, though there is nothing stopping multiple resources - one per condition.
element.comment: If none of the conditions listed have an outcome of "death" specified, that indicates that none of the specified conditions are known to have been the primary cause of death.

element.definition: The actual condition specified. Could be a coded condition (like MI or Diabetes) or a less specific string like 'cancer' depending on how much is known about the condition and the capabilities of the creating system.

element.definition: Indicates what happened as a result of this condition.  If the condition resulted in death, deceased date is captured on the relation.
element.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The result of the condition for the patient; e.g. death, permanent disability, temporary disability, etc.

element.definition: Either the age of onset, range of approximate age or descriptive string can be recorded.  For conditions with multiple occurrences, this describes the first known occurrence.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.
element.requirements: Age of onset of a condition in relatives is predictive of risk for the patient.

If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present
There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.  If value is present, it SHALL be positive.

inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ].source[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="Subject Age at measurement", value<Diagnosis].value[@xsi:typeCode='TS' or 'IVL_TS']  Use originalText for string

element.definition: An area where general notes can be placed about this specific condition.
element.comment: For systems that do not have structured annotations, they can simply communicate a single annotation with no author or time.
